questions.prompt: A settlement guard accuses a traveler of theft. A crowd forms and tempers rise.
questions.context: You're close enough to intervene before it turns ugly.

options.label: Step between them, slow things down, and get both sides talking.
Take charge: separate parties, assign a witness, start a quick check of facts.
Shadow the traveler quietly to see if they ditch anything or meet someone.
Inspect locks/containers for tool marks and likely methods.
Tell the crowd to back off—if violence starts, you'll end it fast.
Pull aside the most reasonable person and broker a face-saving compromise.

questions.prompt: Your group needs to cross a raider-patrolled bridge before nightfall.
questions.context: You have limited ammo and no guarantee of backup.

options.label: Try to negotiate passage with gifts and calm confidence.
Assign roles, set a crossing order, and enforce discipline.
Go ahead alone to scout and signal the safest timing.
Rig a simple distraction (noise/light) to draw patrols away.
Hit hard first: ambush the nearest patrol and push through while they’re stunned.
Change the plan: find an alternate crossing even if it’s longer.

questions.prompt: A sick child needs medicine that only a rival town stocks.
questions.context: They dislike your settlement and overcharge outsiders.

options.label: Appeal to their humanity—make it about the child, not politics.
Bring a small delegation and formalize an agreement for future trade.
Use a cover story and buy quietly without drawing attention.
Offer technical help (repairs/water system fix) as payment.
Threaten consequences if they refuse; make it clear you can enforce it.
Trade something valuable now, then renegotiate later when emotions cool.

questions.prompt: Your radio picks up a distress call from a collapsed building.
questions.context: It could be a trap—or real survivors.

options.label: Approach openly and announce yourself, offering help first.
Organize a perimeter and controlled entry with assigned sectors.
Recon quietly from cover and confirm signs of life before committing.
Assess structural risks and improvise supports before entering.
Go in fast with weapon ready—better to survive than be sorry.
Split effort: one team verifies, one stays mobile for extraction.

questions.prompt: A valuable shipment arrives short; someone in your group skimmed supplies.
questions.context: If you accuse wrong, you lose trust. If you ignore, it repeats.

options.label: Hold a calm meeting and ask for voluntary confession without threats.
Run a structured audit and announce fair consequences.
Set a quiet trap: mark supplies and watch who takes them.
Improve inventory controls (seals, logs, access rules).
Make an example: threaten harsh punishment to deter future theft.
Address root causes: adjust rations/workloads so desperation drops.

questions.prompt: You find a locked pre-war terminal controlling a door to a safe cache.
questions.context: Time is short; you hear movement nearby.

options.label: Call out to the unseen people and offer to split what's inside.
Assign a lookout, a breacher, and a carrier—move as a unit.
Slip away and circle to approach the door from another angle.
Hack the terminal quickly and quietly.
Force entry immediately, accepting noise and risk.
Abandon the cache—survival beats loot when unknowns are close.

questions.prompt: A caravan offers a contract: escort them through a dangerous pass for high pay.
questions.context: Your people need caps, but losses would cripple you.

options.label: Negotiate safer terms: less pay, more time, fewer risks.
Accept and drill your team; set strict engagement rules and fallback points.
Take the job alone as advance scout to reduce exposure for others.
Improve gear and comms first; only accept once readiness is real.
Take it—risk is the price of profit. Hit threats hard.
Decline and seek smaller, repeatable income sources.

questions.prompt: A recruit panics during a firefight and freezes in the open.
questions.context: Seconds matter.

options.label: Shout clear reassurance and guide them step-by-step to cover.
Command: 'Move NOW' and physically pull them behind cover.
Throw a distraction and reposition so they can follow your movement.
Deploy smoke/covering device if you have it.
Leave them—focus on neutralizing the threat first.
Call a buddy system rule after: pair them permanently until confidence returns.

questions.prompt: Your settlement council is deadlocked; no one will compromise.
questions.context: Food stores are dwindling and decisions are overdue.

options.label: Facilitate: let each side speak, summarize, then seek shared goals.
Take responsibility and propose a firm plan with timelines.
Work behind the scenes: build a coalition quietly before the next vote.
Model outcomes: numbers, rations, and schedules to ground debate.
Force the issue: threaten to remove obstructive members.
Create a temporary emergency policy that expires once stability returns.

questions.prompt: You meet a stranger claiming to be from a secret resistance group.
questions.context: They ask you to deliver a package—no questions.

options.label: Refuse gently unless they explain risks and safeguards.
Agree only if you can verify identity and set strict handoff rules.
Accept, but compartmentalize: learn nothing unnecessary and move quietly.
Inspect the package for tracking, explosives, or tampering indicators.
Threaten them for information—if it’s a trap, you’ll make it hurt.
Redirect: connect them to someone better suited while staying out of it.

questions.prompt: A reactor leak is contaminating water. Panic is spreading.
questions.context: Fixing it needs time and coordination.

options.label: Calm people and explain simple steps to reduce exposure.
Declare an emergency plan: rationing, rotations, and restricted zones.
Slip into restricted areas to assess the true source without causing alarm.
Prioritize the technical fix: isolate valves, patch, and test outputs.
Threaten looters and panic-mongers—order by fear if needed.
Set up temporary alternative supply routes while repairs proceed.

questions.prompt: A friend asks you to hide them after they attacked someone in anger.
questions.context: They swear it was justified. Others want them punished.

options.label: Hear them out privately, then encourage surrender with support.
Bring them to leadership and negotiate a controlled accountability process.
Hide them temporarily and investigate what really happened.
Collect evidence: injuries, witnesses, timeline—make the truth provable.
Turn them in immediately—violence must be punished hard.
Arrange restitution: repair harm while preventing future escalation.

questions.prompt: A hostile gang offers 'protection' for a monthly tribute.
questions.context: You can’t match them head-on.

options.label: Negotiate for time and reduce tribute with careful concessions.
Unify the town: militia schedules, watch posts, and contingency plans.
Infiltrate and identify their weak points or internal rivals.
Improve defenses: chokepoints, alarms, reinforced gates.
Strike their leadership in a single decisive hit.
Relocate quietly to a safer position before tribute traps you.

questions.prompt: A trader offers a deal that feels 'too good'—rare ammo for cheap.
questions.context: Could be stolen or bait.

options.label: Ask direct questions politely and watch their reactions.
Set clear terms and verify provenance before purchase.
Buy a small amount first, then tail them to learn the source.
Inspect ammo markings, manufacture patterns, and consistency.
Intimidate them into revealing where it came from.
Decline and offer a fair price—stability beats bargains.

questions.prompt: A patrol reports footprints circling your settlement at night.
questions.context: No attack yet—just watching.

options.label: Increase lanterns and send a message: you're alert, not afraid.
Organize night rotations and assign a response protocol.
Set observation hides and track them back to their base.
Lay quiet early-warning devices (trip lines, cans, chalk).
Send an armed group to hunt them down immediately.
Bait them into a controlled reveal: visible supplies + hidden overwatch.

questions.prompt: You’re offered leadership of a small unit, but it means leaving your home community behind.
questions.context: Both paths matter.

options.label: Stay: your people need steady care more than personal advancement.
Accept and build a successor plan so your community isn’t abandoned.
Accept, but keep your ties quiet—use your new reach to protect them indirectly.
Negotiate resources/guarantees as part of taking the role.
Accept without hesitation—power opens doors, sentiment slows you.
Delay the decision: test-run the role temporarily before committing.

questions.prompt: A firefight ends and you capture an enemy who begs for mercy.
questions.context: Your group is divided on what to do.

options.label: Stabilize them and question them calmly; keep them alive.
Detain them under guard and hold a quick tribunal.
Use them as a controlled informant—release under observation.
Secure weapons, document evidence, and preserve chain-of-custody.
Execute them—future risk eliminated.
Trade them to a nearby authority for supplies and reduced conflict.

questions.prompt: A storm cuts power. Your radio tower dies and morale drops.
questions.context: People look to someone to fix it—or reassure them.

options.label: Keep everyone calm, assign small comforts, and explain what you’ll do next.
Assign teams: repair crew, security, and shelter logistics.
Check for sabotage quietly while others focus on shelter.
Troubleshoot: isolate faults, replace parts, restore minimal function first.
Blame and punish suspected slackers to restore discipline fast.
Improvise alternative comms (runners, signals) until repairs are done.

questions.prompt: A local doctor asks you to escort them to retrieve supplies from a dangerous clinic.
questions.context: They’re vital to your community but not combat-trained.

options.label: Agree and reassure them; prioritize their safety and patient outcomes.
Plan the route, timing, and contingencies; brief them thoroughly.
Scout alone first and only bring them when the path is confirmed.
Prepare protective gear and medical loadout optimally.
Go aggressive: clear the clinic of threats so it’s safe afterwards.
Find a trade instead—swap with another town to avoid the trip.

questions.prompt: A stranger offers to teach you a valuable skill, but wants a personal secret in return.
questions.context: The skill could change your future.

options.label: Decline politely; trust shouldn’t be bought with vulnerability.
Set boundaries and negotiate fair exchange without coercion.
Offer a harmless decoy secret and assess their intentions.
Offer technical labor or supplies instead of personal info.
Press them hard—if they want leverage, you’ll take it first.
Delay: learn what you can from observation before committing.

questions.prompt: Your team is exhausted. Pushing onward saves time, but mistakes are rising.
questions.context: You must choose the pace.

options.label: Stop early and focus on rest, warmth, and recovery.
Enforce rotations and brief, disciplined rests; keep moving with structure.
Volunteer for the hardest shift so others can recover.
Optimize load distribution and route to reduce fatigue.
Push through—weakness gets people killed later.
Adjust plan: shorter legs, more checkpoints, flexible arrival time.

questions.prompt: You find a damaged robot that could be repaired into a strong ally.
questions.context: Fixing it costs time and parts you might need later.

options.label: Ask nearby settlers if they need help first; avoid drawing attention.
Decide as a group: cost/benefit, then commit with clear roles.
Repair it quietly and keep it hidden until you’re sure it’s safe.
Salvage and repair efficiently; restore minimal function, then upgrade later.
Strip it for parts—no time for luxury projects.
Patch it enough to walk, then relocate and finish later.

questions.prompt: A rival leader spreads rumors that you’re untrustworthy.
questions.context: Your alliances are at risk.

options.label: Address it openly with calm facts and personal sincerity.
Confront them in public with a structured challenge and demand accountability.
Undermine them quietly: gather proof of their lies and reveal at the right time.
Create a transparent record system so your actions speak for themselves.
Threaten them—fear shuts mouths faster than truth.
Shift focus: strengthen alliances directly and let the rumor die from irrelevance.

questions.prompt: You’re offered a high-paying job to sabotage another group’s water supply.
questions.context: It’s profitable, but impacts civilians.

options.label: Refuse and explain why; no profit is worth innocent suffering.
Refuse and warn the target group to strengthen defenses.
Pretend to accept to learn who’s behind it and stop them quietly.
Advise the employer on non-lethal alternatives that still meet their goals.
Take the job—survival is survival. Don’t moralize.
Counter-offer: accept only if it targets infrastructure, not civilians, and reduces harm.

questions.prompt: A rescue mission is possible, but only if someone volunteers for the most dangerous route.
questions.context: You’re the most capable person available.

options.label: Volunteer, but bring someone along so nobody dies alone.
Choose the volunteer based on readiness and assign strong support.
Go alone and move fast; the fewer exposed, the better.
Reduce danger with equipment, maps, and contingency plans first.
Go in loud and hard—clear the route by force.
Find a third way: negotiate, trade, or delay until conditions improve.

questions.prompt: A workshop fire breaks out. Supplies and tools are at risk.
questions.context: People are shouting conflicting instructions.

options.label: Calm panic, guide evacuations, and keep people from rushing in.
Take command: bucket line, rescue team, and perimeter roles.
Slip inside quickly to retrieve the most critical item before it’s lost.
Cut fuel sources, isolate ignition points, and use the right extinguishing method.
Force people into action with harsh orders—no time for feelings.
Prioritize: save lives first, then only the top survival-critical equipment.

questions.prompt: You’re asked to train new recruits who have never fought before.
questions.context: Threats are increasing; you need them ready soon.

options.label: Start gentle: confidence, safety, and teamwork before drills.
Build a structured program with clear standards and progression.
Teach by shadowing: pair them with experienced members quietly.
Focus on practical skills: maintenance, cover usage, and basic tactics.
Break them in fast with stress drills—fear inoculation works.
Prioritize role-fit: scouts, medics, guards—train based on strengths.

questions.prompt: A powerful faction offers protection if you provide intelligence on your neighbors.
questions.context: Refusal might bring trouble. Acceptance betrays trust.

options.label: Refuse politely and emphasize neutrality and peace.
Refuse formally and coordinate a defensive pact with neighbors.
Feed them harmless misinformation to buy time and reduce threat.
Create a transparent info-sharing charter so spying becomes harder.
Accept and rationalize it—survival requires hard choices.
Redirect them toward legitimate trade agreements instead of intel.

questions.prompt: A raider camp is vulnerable tonight. Taking it out could save lives later.
questions.context: But you risk casualties and retaliation.

options.label: Warn nearby settlements and avoid escalation unless attacked.
Plan a joint operation: intel, roles, exfil routes, and rules.
Infiltrate to sabotage supplies and reduce their capability without open war.
Set traps and defensive works so they break themselves on your perimeter.
Hit them hard—decapitate leadership and make it permanent.
Target only their mobility (fuel, ammo) then leave; reduce risk of revenge.

questions.prompt: A stranger asks to join your group. Their story checks out—but you feel unsure.
questions.context: Turning them away feels cruel; accepting could be dangerous.

options.label: Give them a chance with kindness and a clear support path.
Accept with probation, rules, and a sponsor responsible for them.
Accept but compartmentalize: limited access until trust is earned.
Verify with practical checks: skills test, references, and consistency.
Reject them harshly—weak links get you killed.
Redirect them to a safer allied settlement better suited for intake.

questions.prompt: Your ammo supply is low. You can craft more, but it will be imperfect and risky.
questions.context: You might need it soon.

options.label: Seek trade first—avoid dangerous shortcuts.
Implement strict rationing and assign ammo by mission priority.
Scavenge alone for better materials to reduce failure rates.
Craft carefully: quality control, test batches, and documentation.
Make it fast and accept misfires—quantity wins fights.
Switch doctrine: avoid firefights, use deterrence and mobility.

questions.prompt: A friend confides they’re overwhelmed and close to breaking.
questions.context: You’re busy, but ignoring it could cost them—and the group.

options.label: Sit with them now and listen—no agenda, just support.
Arrange formal support: rest rotation, buddy system, and clear duties.
Check on them quietly and shield them from extra scrutiny.
Provide practical tools: breathing drills, routines, and coping plans.
Tell them to toughen up—people depend on them.
Redistribute responsibilities to reduce load without shaming them.

questions.prompt: A mission fails. People blame each other and morale collapses.
questions.context: You need recovery and learning—fast.

options.label: Hold a calm debrief focused on feelings and facts, not blame.
Run a structured after-action review with clear lessons and changes.
Identify the real root cause quietly and address it without public drama.
Create checklists/procedures so the failure mode can’t recur.
Punish someone to restore order and deter mistakes.
Change tactics immediately and adapt—don’t overanalyze under pressure.

questions.prompt: You discover evidence that a respected leader has been skimming resources.
questions.context: Exposing it could fracture the community.

options.label: Confront them privately and offer a path to make it right.
Bring it to a council process with evidence and fair oversight.
Use the information as leverage to force better outcomes quietly.
Secure evidence: copies, witnesses, and logs before any accusation.
Expose them publicly immediately—let the crowd decide.
Time the reveal: stabilize supplies first, then address leadership reform.

questions.prompt: A firefight is inevitable, but you can choose the battleground.
questions.context: Your goal is survival, not glory.

options.label: Try one last negotiation to avoid bloodshed altogether.
Pick terrain deliberately and assign arcs, cover, and fallback positions.
Set an ambush with minimal exposure and an escape route.
Engineer the space: barriers, choke points, and field expedient cover.
Charge before they’re ready—aggression wins momentum.
Feint and reposition mid-fight—keep them reacting to you.

questions.prompt: You’re offered a role as an information broker—high profit, high risk.
questions.context: You’d know secrets that get people killed.

options.label: Decline—information power corrodes communities.
Accept with ethics: rules on harm, consent, and verification.
Accept but stay invisible; compartmentalize everything.
Build secure systems: codes, dead drops, and redundancy.
Use leverage ruthlessly—people pay to stay safe.
Pilot it small: limited clients, limited scope, and exit plans.

questions.prompt: A team member is careless with weapon safety, risking accidents.
questions.context: They’re talented, but reckless.

options.label: Coach them gently and explain consequences without humiliation.
Enforce standards: mandatory retraining and temporary restriction.
Pair them with a strict mentor quietly to correct behavior.
Introduce mechanical/kit safeguards to reduce human error.
Threaten punishment—fear fixes habits fast.
Move them into a role where their talent matters but safety risk is lower.

questions.prompt: You have one dose of anti-venom. Two people are bitten.
questions.context: One is a valuable specialist; one is a child.

options.label: Give it to the child—no debate.
Make a transparent decision with witnesses and agreed principles.
Quietly give it to the one most likely to survive and help later.
Attempt a partial dose strategy and improvise supportive care for both.
Decide purely by utility: specialist first.
Seek immediate trade/aid while stabilizing both—buy time.

questions.prompt: A settlement festival is planned, but security is thin.
questions.context: Some say cancel; others say morale is survival.

options.label: Hold it, but keep it calm and community-focused—reduce risks without fear.
Run it with security structure: entry checks, patrols, and response plans.
Watch quietly for suspicious behavior and intervene early.
Improve lighting, barriers, and alarms—engineering beats panic.
Cancel and enforce curfew—fun isn’t worth vulnerability.
Scale it down: smaller gatherings, staggered times, safer layout.

questions.prompt: You’re lost in ruins. Your map is wrong and daylight is fading.
questions.context: You need a new plan quickly.

options.label: Stop moving, breathe, and reassess calmly before making it worse.
Establish control: pick a rally point, assign bearings, and move as one.
Climb or scout alone to regain orientation without slowing the group.
Use landmarks, stars, and improvised tools to rebuild navigation.
Push fast in one direction—hesitation kills more than wrong turns.
Change objective: secure shelter now, navigate tomorrow.

questions.prompt: A powerful merchant asks you to 'rough up' a competitor—no killing, just a message.
questions.context: It’s lucrative and common in the region.

options.label: Refuse and suggest non-violent competition.
Decline and warn the competitor discreetly to prevent escalation.
Pretend to accept, then sabotage the plan quietly.
Offer mediation terms between them instead—contracts over bruises.
Do it—fear is currency. Make the message memorable.
Counter-offer: provide security assessment instead of violence.

questions.prompt: You’re asked to run a safe house for people being hunted.
questions.context: If discovered, everyone dies.

options.label: Agree because it’s right—and focus on care and stability for them.
Agree and impose strict protocols: vetting, schedules, and compartmentalization.
Agree but keep your role hidden; you’ll run it like a shadow network.
Fortify discreetly: hidden caches, alarms, and escape routes.
Refuse—too risky. You won’t sacrifice your community.
Help indirectly: connect them to a better location and provide supplies.

questions.prompt: A mission requires a convincing disguise and acting skills.
questions.context: Failure means capture.

options.label: Practice empathy: understand the target persona and speak naturally.
Assign roles and scripts; drill until everyone can perform reliably.
Improvise and adapt mid-stream; you’ll blend in by reading the room.
Engineer details: documents, props, and consistent cover story mechanics.
Skip disguise—go armed and accept the fight.
Reduce exposure: shorten time on-site and limit who goes.

questions.prompt: Your group debates whether to expand territory or consolidate and fortify.
questions.context: Expansion increases resources but draws conflict.

options.label: Consolidate: strengthen community and avoid needless enemies.
Choose a structured expansion: phased, defended, and supply-backed.
Expand quietly through influence: trade ties and soft control, not flags.
Run the numbers: logistics, water, labor, and realistic sustainment.
Expand by force—dominance prevents threats later.
Hybrid approach: fortify now, prepare expansion later when conditions align.

questions.prompt: A teammate suggests executing a captured enemy to 'send a message'.
questions.context: You’re responsible for what your group becomes.

options.label: Reject it—your identity matters. No cruelty-as-policy.
Set doctrine: prisoners are handled by rules, not emotions.
Redirect: stage a non-lethal deception that still deters enemies.
Document the captive’s crimes and deliver them to a legitimate authority.
Agree—fear is efficient. Mercy is weakness.
Use restorative leverage: trade, ransom, or intel extraction without killing.

questions.prompt: A generator part is failing. You can fix it now with a risky workaround or wait for proper parts.
questions.context: If it fails completely, you lose heat and water pumps.

options.label: Explain the risk to everyone and choose the safest path even if harder.
Decide and coordinate: controlled downtime, rationing, and repair schedule.
Attempt the workaround quietly at off-hours to avoid panic.
Do the workaround with testing steps and fail-safes.
Do it immediately—if it blows, you’ll deal with it then.
Patch for minimal function now, then replace properly when parts arrive.

questions.prompt: A propaganda flyer campaign is turning locals against you.
questions.context: You don’t control the printing source—yet.

options.label: Counter with calm public outreach and consistent behavior.
Coordinate a message strategy and community allies to rebut it.
Identify the source quietly and disrupt distribution without spectacle.
Produce your own leaflets with verifiable facts and receipts.
Threaten anyone caught spreading it—fear stops rumors.
Change the narrative: demonstrate value through actions, not words.

questions.prompt: You’re offered a chance to steal advanced weapons from a locked facility.
questions.context: Success upgrades your power; failure may kill you.

options.label: Decline—arming up isn’t worth the likely cost.
Plan thoroughly: recon, timing, extraction, and contingencies.
Go in quietly with minimal team and avoid detection entirely.
Approach as a technical problem: bypass systems, disable sensors, open cleanly.
Hit it by force—breach and fight your way out with shock and speed.
Seek alternative acquisition: trade, salvage, or smaller upgrades over time.

questions.prompt: A remote outpost requests help. You can spare only one specialist: medic, engineer, or fighter.
questions.context: All are needed at home too.

options.label: Send the medic—saving lives is the priority.
Choose based on mission needs and plan support logistics for them.
Go yourself so you don’t weaken home defenses with a key person absent.
Send the engineer to stabilize infrastructure so the outpost becomes self-sufficient.
Send the fighter—security first; everything else is secondary.
Send a small mixed kit and remote guidance; reduce dependence on one person.

questions.prompt: You’re offered a chance to reshape a faction from within.
questions.context: It means compromise, secrecy, and long-term risk.

options.label: Decline—your integrity matters more than influence.
Accept openly with clear principles and a visible reform platform.
Accept covertly: operate quietly, build allies, and move slowly.
Accept only with a detailed plan: milestones, resources, and exit conditions.
Accept and take power fast—crush opposition before it forms.
Accept conditionally: test the waters, adapt, and bail if harm increases.
